questions.text: A 22-year-old male, who survived a serious road traffic accident on NH-16 two months ago, now reports vivid nightmares of the accident, persistent avoidance of the highway, and sudden, intrusive memories of the event. He also feels hyper-alert and easily startled by traffic sounds. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of nightmares, avoidance, intrusive memories (flashbacks), and hyperarousal for more than one month following a traumatic event is characteristic of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD).

Definition and Key Features:

  • PTSD occurs after exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence.
  • The core features include:
    • Intrusion symptoms (e.g., flashbacks, nightmares)
    • Avoidance of trauma-related reminders
    • Negative alterations in mood and cognition
    • Hyperarousal (e.g., hypervigilance, exaggerated startle response)

Aetiology and Pathophysiology:

  • Thought to involve heightened activity in the amygdala and impaired regulation by the prefrontal cortex.
  • Dysregulation of noradrenergic and serotonergic systems contributes to symptoms.

Clinical Features:

  • Re-experiencing (nightmares, flashbacks)
  • Avoidance of reminders of the trauma
  • Negative thoughts and emotional numbness
  • Hyperarousal symptoms (insomnia, irritability)

Investigations and Diagnosis:

  • Diagnosis is clinically based on DSM-5 criteria; no specific laboratory tests.
  • Symptoms persist for more than one month and cause significant functional impairment.

Management:

  • First-line: Trauma-focused CBT.
  • SSRIs (e.g., sertraline, paroxetine) are FDA-approved for PTSD.
  • Prazosin may be helpful for trauma-related nightmares.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acute Stress Disorder (Option A): Incorrect because symptoms develop within 3 days to 1 month of trauma, whereas PTSD requires persistence beyond 1 month. Acute Stress Disorder can be a precursor to PTSD, but it is a separate diagnosis.

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (Option C): Incorrect because OCD involves recurrent, intrusive thoughts (obsessions) and compulsive rituals, not trauma-specific flashbacks and avoidance behaviours. It lacks the direct link to a traumatic event.

Major Depressive Disorder (Option D): Incorrect because MDD presents with persistent low mood and loss of interest in activities, not the hallmark intrusive trauma-related memories and avoidance seen in PTSD. Although depression can coexist, it does not explain the trauma-focused symptoms here.

questions.text: A 36-year-old businessman who survived a serious car accident 4 months ago complains of "jitteriness" when driving to work and is currently using public transportation because of his anxiety. He reports episodes of "spacing out" for several minutes, difficulty concentrating at work, persistent sadness, poor sleep, and weight loss due to decreased appetite. His job performance has declined significantly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with classic symptoms of Major Depressive Disorder (MDD): persistent low mood, anhedonia, poor sleep, weight loss, poor concentration, and functional impairment.
  • Although he experienced a traumatic event (car accident), his prominent depressive symptoms without hallmark PTSD features (e.g., flashbacks, avoidance, hyperarousal) align more with MDD.
  • MDD is commonly triggered by stress or trauma and can coexist with PTSD, but in this scenario, the core depressive features predominate.

Definition and Key Features:

  • MDD is characterised by at least 2 weeks of persistent depressed mood or anhedonia plus associated symptoms (e.g., appetite changes, sleep disturbance, fatigue, poor concentration, feelings of worthlessness).
  • It often follows a significant psychosocial stressor, as seen in this patient's history of a serious accident.

Aetiology and Pathophysiology:

  • Involves monoamine dysregulation (serotonin, norepinephrine, dopamine) and altered HPA axis function.
  • Stressful life events can precipitate depressive episodes by triggering biological vulnerability.

Clinical Features:

  • Low mood and anhedonia
  • Sleep disturbance (insomnia or hypersomnia)
  • Appetite changes with weight loss
  • Poor concentration and decision-making ability
  • Fatigue and psychomotor changes
  • Feelings of worthlessness and guilt
  • Possible suicidal ideation in severe cases

Investigations and Diagnosis:

  • Diagnosis is clinical based on DSM-5 criteria.
  • Evaluate for medical causes (e.g., thyroid dysfunction, neurologic injuries).
  • Screen for comorbid substance use or PTSD symptoms.

Management:

  • First-line treatments include SSRIs and psychotherapy (CBT or interpersonal therapy).
  • Monitor for suicidality and functional impairment.

Explanation of Other Options:

Panic Disorder (Option B): Incorrect because panic disorder involves recurrent, unexpected panic attacks with sudden intense fear and physical symptoms (e.g., palpitations, shortness of breath), not chronic low mood and anhedonia.

Social Anxiety Disorder (Option C): Incorrect because social anxiety disorder involves intense fear and avoidance of social interactions due to embarrassment, not the pervasive low mood, anhedonia, and weight loss seen here. This patient's functional decline and weight loss are more consistent with depression.

Temporal Lobe Epilepsy (Option D): Incorrect because temporal lobe epilepsy presents with focal seizures, déjà vu, olfactory hallucinations, and automatisms, not sustained low mood, poor sleep, and weight loss. "Spacing out" in this context likely represents dissociation related to trauma, not seizure activity.

questions.text: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is associated with which of the following types of learning behaviours in its pathogenesis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • PTSD involves both classical conditioning and instrumental (operant) learning in the development and maintenance of symptoms.
  • Classical conditioning: The trauma (unconditioned stimulus) becomes paired with neutral stimuli (e.g., sights, smells, sounds of the trauma), turning them into conditioned stimuli that elicit fear responses. (Option A)
  • Instrumental learning (operant conditioning): Individuals learn to avoid these conditioned stimuli to reduce distress, reinforcing avoidance behaviours. (Option B)

Definition and Key Features:

  • PTSD develops after exposure to trauma and involves re-experiencing, avoidance, negative mood/cognition, and hyperarousal.
  • Learned fear responses and avoidance maintain the disorder's symptoms and contribute to chronicity.

Aetiology and Pathophysiology:

  • Fear conditioning in the amygdala and impaired regulation by the prefrontal cortex underlie the development of these maladaptive behaviours.
  • Dysregulation of noradrenergic and serotonergic systems also plays a role.

Clinical Features:

  • Intrusive memories and nightmares
  • Avoidance of trauma-related cues
  • Emotional numbing and negative thinking
  • Heightened startle response and hypervigilance

Investigations and Diagnosis:

  • Clinical diagnosis based on DSM-5 criteria.
  • No specific laboratory tests; it is important to rule out medical conditions and other psychiatric disorders.

Management:

  • Trauma-focused CBT with exposure to extinguish conditioned responses and reduce avoidance behaviours.
  • SSRIs for symptom control and prazosin for trauma-related nightmares.

questions.text:
According to DSM-5, which of the following symptom clusters must be present for a diagnosis of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)?
1. Intrusion symptoms
2. Avoidance symptoms
3. Hyperarousal symptoms
4. Cognitive distortions and negative mood
5. Dissociation symptoms
6. Somatic preoccupations
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for PTSD require the presence of all four core symptom clusters:
    • Intrusion symptoms (e.g., intrusive memories, nightmares, flashbacks)
    • Avoidance symptoms (avoiding trauma reminders)
    • Negative alterations in mood and cognition (e.g., emotional numbness, guilt, negative beliefs)
    • Hyperarousal symptoms (e.g., hypervigilance, irritability, sleep disturbance)
  • These symptoms must be present for more than one month and cause significant functional impairment.

Definition and Key Features:

  • PTSD follows exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence.
  • It involves intrusive re-experiencing of the trauma, persistent avoidance, negative emotional states, and heightened arousal.

Aetiology and Pathophysiology:

  • Amygdala hyperactivity and impaired prefrontal cortex regulation of fear and threat perception.
  • Involvement of noradrenergic and serotonergic dysregulation in maintaining symptoms.

Clinical Features:

  • Nightmares, flashbacks, emotional numbing
  • Avoidance of trauma-related stimuli
  • Persistent negative mood and beliefs
  • Heightened startle response and poor sleep

Investigations and Diagnosis:

  • Clinical diagnosis using DSM-5 criteria.
  • No confirmatory lab tests; assess for comorbidities and functional impairment.

Management:

  • Trauma-focused CBT is the mainstay of treatment.
  • SSRIs (sertraline, paroxetine) are approved for PTSD pharmacotherapy.
  • Prazosin may be helpful for trauma-related nightmares.

choices.text: Witnessing the traumatic event as it occurred to others
Learning that the traumatic event (violent or accidental) occurred to close family members/ close friends
All of the above can cause PTSD

questions.text: PTSD refers to exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence in which of the following ways?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • PTSD can develop when a person is exposed to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence in one or more of the following ways:
    • Directly experiencing the traumatic event. (Option A)
    • Witnessing, in person, the traumatic event as it occurred to others. (Option B)
    • Learning that the traumatic event occurred to a close family member or close friend, if the event was violent or accidental. (Option C)
    • Experiencing repeated or extreme exposure to aversive details of traumatic events (e.g., first responders collecting human remains).
  • This broad definition helps recognise that PTSD can develop not only from direct exposure but also from indirect exposure to trauma.

Definition and Key Features:

  • PTSD involves intrusive re-experiencing, avoidance of reminders, negative alterations in cognition/mood, and hyperarousal symptoms.
  • Symptoms persist for more than one month and cause significant distress or functional impairment.

Aetiology and Pathophysiology:

  • Amygdala hyperactivity and prefrontal cortex dysfunction disrupt the regulation of fear responses.
  • Neurotransmitter imbalances in noradrenergic and serotonergic systems contribute to symptom maintenance.

Clinical Features:

  • Intrusive flashbacks and nightmares
  • Emotional numbing and social withdrawal
  • Hypervigilance and sleep disturbances
  • Avoidance of trauma reminders

Investigations and Diagnosis:

  • Clinical diagnosis using DSM-5 criteria.
  • Important to differentiate from other trauma-related and mood disorders.

Management:

  • Trauma-focused CBT is the first-line treatment.
  • SSRIs (sertraline, paroxetine) are FDA-approved for PTSD.
  • Prazosin may reduce trauma-related nightmares.

choices.text: The woman who lost her job and the man whose father had surgery
The woman who was sexually assaulted and the boy who witnessed the fatal car accident
The woman who was sexually assaulted and the man who witnessed the planned surgery
The woman who lost her job and the man who witnessed the planned surgery

questions.text:
Case 1: A 20-year-old woman experiences nightmares, flashbacks, and hypervigilance after a sexual assault.
Case 2: A 17-year-old boy has persistent intrusive memories after witnessing his mother die in a car accident.
Case 3: A 25-year-old woman lost her job due to poor performance; she feels stressed but has no flashbacks.
Case 4: A 30-year-old man reports anxiety after his father underwent planned surgery.
Who among them is at the highest risk of developing Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • PTSD is most strongly associated with exposure to life-threatening, violent, or highly traumatic events.
  • Both sexual assault and witnessing a sudden, accidental death (e.g., a car accident) meet these criteria in DSM-5 and significantly increase the risk for PTSD.
  • Stressors like job loss and planned surgeries, although challenging, do not meet the threshold of exposure to death, serious injury, or sexual violence that defines trauma in PTSD.

Definition and Key Features:

  • PTSD develops after exposure to trauma involving actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence.
  • Core features include intrusive symptoms, avoidance, negative mood, cognitive changes, and hyperarousal.

Aetiology and Pathophysiology:

  • Involves dysfunction in the amygdala-prefrontal cortex circuit responsible for fear processing and regulation.
  • Dysregulation of noradrenergic and serotonergic systems plays a role in persistent symptoms.

Clinical Features:

  • Intrusive flashbacks and nightmares related to the traumatic event
  • Avoidance of reminders and social withdrawal
  • Negative mood, guilt, or numbness
  • Heightened startle response and sleep disturbance

Investigations and Diagnosis:

  • Clinical diagnosis using DSM-5 criteria.
  • Important to differentiate from adjustment disorders and mood disorders.

Management:

  • Trauma-focused CBT is the cornerstone of therapy.
  • SSRIs (sertraline, paroxetine) as first-line pharmacotherapy.
  • Prazosin may help with trauma-related nightmares.

Explanation of Other Options:

The woman who lost her job and the man whose father had surgery (Option A): Incorrect because neither job loss nor a planned surgery typically constitutes the overwhelming, life-threatening stressor required for PTSD.

The woman who was sexually assaulted and the man who witnessed the planned surgery (Option C): Incorrect because the man’s experience with a planned surgery does not meet DSM-5's trauma definition.

The woman who lost her job and the man who witnessed the planned surgery (Option D): Incorrect because neither scenario involves direct or indirect exposure to violent trauma or threat to life.

choices.text: Negative alterations in mood and cognition

questions.text: A 20-year-old nurse was attacked in a parking lot near the hospital where she worked, experiencing a brutal assault and rape. Since then, she has recurrent distressing memories and nightmares of the incident, flashbacks where she feels as if she is reliving the event, and intense distress whenever she sees someone resembling her attacker or finds herself in a dark place. These symptoms are best categorised as belonging to which symptom domain of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The nurse's experiences of recurrent, involuntary, and intrusive distressing memories (nightmares, flashbacks) and her strong emotional and physical reactions to trauma-related reminders are characteristic of the intrusion symptom domain of PTSD.
  • DSM-5 includes these features as a core cluster necessary for diagnosis.

Definition and Key Features:

  • PTSD is a trauma- and stressor-related disorder following exposure to life-threatening or overwhelming violence (e.g., sexual assault, physical attack).
  • The disorder involves four key symptom clusters:
    • Intrusion
    • Avoidance
    • Negative alterations in cognition and mood
    • Hyperarousal

Aetiology and Pathophysiology:

  • Dysfunction in the amygdala (fear centre) and prefrontal cortex (emotion regulation) sustains intrusive trauma memories.
  • Neurobiological changes in noradrenergic and serotonergic pathways contribute to symptom maintenance.

Clinical Features:

  • Intrusion: Flashbacks, nightmares, distressing memories triggered by reminders.
  • Avoidance: Efforts to avoid reminders of the trauma (e.g., avoiding the location or people that remind her of the attacker).
  • Negative mood and cognition: Emotional numbness, guilt, distorted blame.
  • Hyperarousal: Heightened startle response, insomnia, irritability.

Investigations and Diagnosis:

  • Diagnosis is clinical using DSM-5 criteria.
  • Important to differentiate from other anxiety or mood disorders.

Management:

  • Trauma-focused CBT and exposure-based therapy to reduce intrusive memories.
  • SSRIs (sertraline, paroxetine) are first-line medications for PTSD.
  • Prazosin may help with trauma-related nightmares.

Explanation of Other Options:

Hyperarousal symptoms (Option B): Incorrect because these involve sleep disturbance, exaggerated startle response, and hypervigilance-separate from the intrusive experiences described in this case.

Negative alterations in mood and cognition (Option C): Incorrect because while these can also occur in PTSD, the scenario highlights recurrent, involuntary memories and flashbacks, not negative beliefs or emotional numbness.

All of the above (Option D): Incorrect because while PTSD encompasses all four clusters, the question specifically describes the intrusion cluster.

choices.text: Irritable and reckless behaviour, exaggerated startle response, increased alertness, and difficulty in concentration
Irritable and reckless behaviour, increased alertness, flashbacks, nightmares
Avoidance behaviour, decreased concentration, sleep disturbance
Traumatic amnesia, negative emotions, feelings of detachment, depersonalization

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the hyperarousal spectrum of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • These features represent the hyperarousal cluster in PTSD, which includes persistent symptoms of heightened physiological and emotional reactivity.
  • This cluster reflects autonomic overactivity and impaired emotion regulation in PTSD.

Key Features of the Hyperarousal Spectrum:

  • Irritable and aggressive behaviour: Outbursts of anger, aggression, or irritability without clear provocation.
  • Reckless or self-destructive behaviour: Such as reckless driving or substance misuse, often as a maladaptive coping mechanism.
  • Hypervigilance: Heightened alertness and exaggerated concern for safety.
  • Exaggerated startle response: Excessive reactivity to unexpected noises or stimuli.
  • Difficulty concentrating: Distractibility due to constant scanning for threat.
  • Sleep disturbance: Difficulty falling or staying asleep, restless or poor-quality sleep.
  • These symptoms are driven by persistent activation of the sympathetic nervous system and dysregulation of noradrenergic pathways in PTSD.

Explanation of Other Options:

Irritable and reckless behaviour, increased alertness, flashbacks, nightmares (Option B): Incorrect because flashbacks and nightmares are intrusion symptoms, not hyperarousal features.

Avoidance behaviour, decreased concentration, sleep disturbance (Option C): Incorrect because avoidance is a separate cluster, while decreased concentration and sleep disturbance alone do not fully define hyperarousal.

Traumatic amnesia, negative emotions, feelings of detachment, depersonalization (Option D): Incorrect because these belong to the negative alterations in mood and cognition cluster, not hyperarousal.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was recently rescued from a building fire and has had flashbacks, distressing memories, and disturbed dreams about the event for about 20 days. Which of the following characteristics differentiates Acute Stress Disorder (ASD) from Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The key difference between Acute Stress Disorder (ASD) and Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) in this scenario is the duration of symptoms.
  • ASD is diagnosed when symptoms persist from 3 days up to 1 month after the traumatic event.
  • PTSD is diagnosed if symptoms last more than 1 month after trauma exposure.
  • In this case, the symptoms have lasted 20 days, aligning with ASD.

Features Differentiating ASD and PTSD:

  • Timing: ASD (≤1 month), PTSD (>1 month).
  • Symptom clusters: Both can have intrusive symptoms (flashbacks, nightmares) and hyperarousal, but time is the defining factor.
  • Progression: ASD may resolve or evolve into PTSD if symptoms persist beyond 1 month.

Explanation of Other Options:

Severity of stressor (Option B): Both ASD and PTSD require exposure to severe trauma - this does not differentiate them. Both disorders share the same stressor criteria in DSM-5.

Number of symptoms (Option C): Although the number and types of symptoms can vary, the duration of symptoms remains the principal distinguishing factor.

All of the above (Option D): Only time duration definitively differentiates ASD from PTSD, while stressor severity and number of symptoms are not the defining criteria.

questions.text: A patient with Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) undergoes a psychotherapy session where they focus on the lateral movement of the clinician's finger while recalling distressing memories of the trauma. The technique aims to help them process the event while in a state of deep relaxation. What is this technique called?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • EMDR is a structured psychotherapeutic approach combining trauma exposure and cognitive processing with directed bilateral stimulation (like following finger movements).
  • The patient simultaneously maintains a mental image of the trauma, allowing them to process distressing memories while staying relaxed and engaged.
  • EMDR has shown efficacy in reducing PTSD symptoms and is recommended in certain cases of trauma-related disorders.

Mechanism:

  • It is believed that bilateral stimulation (e.g., eye movements) facilitates adaptive information processing, helping the brain to integrate and resolve traumatic memories.

Explanation of Other Options:

Systematic desensitisation (Option A): Incorrect because it uses graduated exposure to feared stimuli paired with relaxation techniques, not bilateral stimulation like EMDR. It's used primarily in phobias.

Guided imagery (Option B): Incorrect because guided imagery involves visualising calming scenarios to reduce anxiety, but does not involve trauma processing or eye movements.

Implosive therapy (Option D): Incorrect because this is an intense exposure technique where the patient is confronted directly with feared stimuli to reduce anxiety responses, not the controlled and bilateral reprocessing seen in EMDR.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male paramedical staff member presents with a dysphoric mood, anxiety, and frequent awakenings at night that have persisted for over 6 months after he recovered from significant financial debt. These symptoms initially began 2 years ago after experiencing severe financial losses, but continued even after regaining financial stability. What is the most appropriate current diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Although adjustment disorder was likely initially present (as symptoms arose in response to a stressor within 3 months), it is diagnosed only if symptoms resolve within 6 months after the stressor or its consequences.
  • Because his symptoms persisted beyond 6 months after resolving his financial difficulties, adjustment disorder is no longer appropriate.
  • Instead, the persistence of dysphoria, anxiety, insomnia, and feelings of worthlessness meets the criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD).

Key Points:

  • Adjustment disorder: Symptoms develop in response to an identifiable stressor within 3 months and do not persist beyond 6 months after the stressor ends.
  • MDD: Diagnosed when symptoms (depressed mood, anhedonia, vegetative signs) last ≥2 weeks and cause significant distress or impairment, regardless of initial stressor.

Explanation of other options:

Adjustment disorder (Option A): Incorrect because the DSM-5 specifies that adjustment disorder cannot be diagnosed if symptoms persist more than 6 months after the end of the stressor or its consequences.
